name: src/Bezier.js
src/CanvasCompositor.js
CanvasCompositor
description:
The CanvasCompositor class is the entry-point to usage of the `canvas-compositor`.
The application programmer is expected to hand over low-level control of the canvas
context to the high-level classes and methods exposed by CanvasCompositor.

The CanvasCompositor class establishes an event dispatcher, animation loop, and scene graph for
compositions.

name: constructor
description:
The CanvasCompositor class establishes an event dispatcher, animation loop, and scene graph for
compositions

params.name: canvas
params.description: This should be a canvas, either from the DOM or an equivalent API

name: targetObject
description: the object currently selected for interaction

name: targetObject
description: the object currently selected for interaction

name: scene
description: the root of the scene graph. add primitives to this to compose an image

name: mouseX
description: get the X position of the mouse on the canvas

name: mouseY
description: get the Y position of the mouse on the canvas

name: _animationLoop
description:
The animation loop for this instance of CanvasCompositor.
Upon receipt of the animation frame from `requestAnimationFrame`, the loop will check
whether enough time has passed to redraw for the target framerate.
It will only draw if somewhere along the scene graph, an object needs updating.
There is no need to invoke this directly, the constructor will do it.

name: registerEvent
description: add an event to the event registry

params.name: eventType
params.description: the name of the type of event

params.name: callback
params.description: the callback to be triggered when the event occurs

name: removeEvent
description: remove an event to the event registry

params.name: eventType
params.description: the name of the type of event

params.name: callback
params.description: the callback to be removed from the event

name: _bindEvents
description:
attach interaction events to the canvas. the canvas compositor dispatches
events to relevant objects through bridges to the scene graph

name: _handleMouseDown
description:
bridge the mouse down event on the canvas to the
the objects in the scene graph

name: _handleMouseUp
description:
bridge the mouse up event on the canvas to the
the objects in the scene graph

name: _handleMouseMove
description:
bridge the mouse move event on the canvas to the
the objects in the scene graph

name: _handleClick
description:
bridge the click event on the canvas to the
the objects in the scene graph

name: _handleMouseOut
description:
bridge the mouse out event on the canvas to the
the objects in the scene graph

name: init
description: The initialization function

determine whether the point is in the object
basically just the pythagorean theorem

return.description: whether or not the point is in the object

name: src/Composition.js
Composition
description:
The Composition class is an extension of the Primitive that is
composed of other extensions of the Primitive. The Composition
is used to establish the Scene graph as the parent of all other
objects on screen. This is the key abstraction of the [composite
pattern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Composite_pattern): an
action taken on the parent element acts upon all of the children,
and transatively, all of their children.

params.name: options
params.description: object settings

name: children
description: children of this composition

name: boundingBox
description: the bounding box of the composition (i.e., the containing bounds of all the children of this composition)

name: childrenAt
description: the an array of children that are found at (x, y)

params.name: x
params.description: the x coordinate

params.name: y
params.description: the y coordinate

return.description: childrenAt all the children below the point

name: childAt
description: get the top-most child at the (x, y)

params.name: x
params.description: the x coordinate

params.name: y
params.description: the y coordinate

return.description: childAt the first child below the point

name: addChild
description: add a child to this composition

params.name: child
params.description: the child to be added

name: removeChild
description: remove a child from this composition

params.name: child
params.description: the child to be removed

name: src/Line.js
Line
description: A line

name: constructor
description:
A Line can be defined by two points, p1 and p2, through
which it passes. Here, an anchor point is supplied for p1,
and a unit vector, direction, is added to it to provided
the second.

name: intersectionWith
description: determine the location that this line intersects with another, if at all

params.name: l
params.description: the Line to test for intersection against this Line

return.description: the vector of the location of intersection, or null if the lines are parallel

name: intersection
description: determine the location that these lines intersect, if at all

params.name: l1
params.description: the first Line to test for intersection

params.name: l2
params.description: the second Line to test for intersection

return.description: the vector of the location of intersection, or null if the lines are parallel

name: src/PrimitiveComponent.js
PrimitiveComponent
description:
The base class of things that may be drawn on the canvas.
All drawable objects should inherit from this class.
Typically, it is unnecessary for application programmers to
call this directly, although they may wish to extend their own
classes with it.

name: _needsDraw
description: does the object need to be redrawn?

name: _needsRender
description: does the object need to be rendered?

name: _scaleWidth
description: the horizontal scale of the object. defaults to 1

name: _scaleHeight
description: the vertical scale of the object. defaults to 1

name: _d
description:
d is for "displacement": a 2D Vector object representing cartesian coordinate
position relative to its parent composition (or [0,0] if this is the scene composition)

name: style
description: style options for this particular object. these are standard context styles

name: draggable
description: if true, the object can be dragged around the canvas

name: _prerenderingCanvas
description:
the prerendering canvas is used to avoid performing mutliple draw operations on the
visible, main canvas. this minimizes the time needed to render by prerendering on a
canvas only as large as necessary for the object

name: _prerenderingContext
description: the 2D context of the prerendering canvas.

name: _parent
description:
the parent object of this object. with the exception of the scene composition itself,
the root of all objects ancestry should be the scene composition

name: onmousedown
description: a callback for the mousedown event.

name: onmouseup
description: a callback for the mouseup event.

name: onmousemove
description: a callback for the mousemove event.

name: onmouseout
description: a callback for the mouseout event.

name: onclick
description: a callback for the click event.

name: offset
description:
the global offset of the object on the canvas.
this is the sum of this object's displacement
and all of its ancestry.

name: needsDraw
description:
returns true whenever the object needs to be re-drawn to canvas.
when true, this will indicate to the parent tree of composing objects that
the object needs to be re-drawn on the next animation loop.

objects need to be updated when their displacement changes, or when any thing
that requires a rerender occurs.

name: needsDraw
description:
set to true whenever the object needs to be re-drawn to canvas.
when true, this will indicate to the parent tree of composing objects that
the object needs to be re-drawn on the next animation loop.

objects need to be updated when their displacement changes, or when any thing
that requires a rerender occurs.

name: needsRender
description:
returns true whenever the object's properties have changed such that
it needs to be rendered differently

1. scale change
1. physical property change (height, width, radius, etc.)
1. color change

name: needsRender
description:
set to true whenever the object's properties have changed such that
it needs to be rendered differently

1. scale change
1. physical property change (height, width, radius, etc.)
1. color change

name: scaleWidth
description: return the horizontal scale of the object - defaults to 1

name: scaleWidth
description: set the horizontal scale of the object - defaults to 1

name: scaleHeight
description: return the vertical scale of the object - defaults to 1

name: scaleHeight
description: set the vertical scale of the object - defaults to 1

params.name: val
params.description: the vertical scale

name: scale
description: return an object containing the vertical and horizontal scale

name: scale
description: set the scale width and height in one go

name: compoundScale
description: return the scale of the object, compounded with the parent object's scale

name: d
description: d is for displacement - returns a vector

name: d
description: d is for displacement - accepts a vector

params.name: val
params.description: a vector

name: parent
description: get the parent of the object. all objects except the scene graph should have a parent

name: parent
description: set the parent of the object. all objects except the scene graph should have a parent

params.name: val
params.description: a composition

name: enableDragging
description: enable dragging by setting the onmousedown event callback

name: disableDragging
description: disable dragging by removing event callbacks

name: dragStart
description: when dragging starts, update events

params.name: e
params.description: the event object

name: drag
description: update d as the object is moved around

params.name: e
params.description: the event object

name: dragEnd
description: when dragging ends, update events

params.name: e
params.description: the event object

name: draw
description: draw the object to canvas, render it if necessary

params.name: context
params.description: the final canvas context where this will be drawn

params.name: offset
params.description: the offset on the canvas - optional, used for prerendering

name: render
description:
this method must be overridden by a subclass.

the render method should be implemented by subclasses

name: pointIsInBoundingBox
description: check whether the point specified lies *inside* this objects bounding box

params.name: x
params.description: the x coordinate

params.name: y
params.description: the y coordinate

return.description: whether the point is within the bounding box

name: pointIsInObject
description:
check whether the point is within the object.
this method should be overridden by subclassess

params.name: x
params.description: the x coordinate

params.name: y
params.description: the y coordinate

return.description: whether the point is in the object, as implemented by inheriting classes

name: moveToFront
description: move the object on top of other objects (render last)

name: moveToBack
description: move the object below the other objects (render first)

name: moveForward
description: move the object forward in the stack (drawn later)

name: moveBackward
description: move the object backward in the stack (drawn sooner)

content:
# canvas-compositor
A light, performant canvas compositor 

# Getting started

You should be able to include the compiled files from the dist directory in any HTML page, which will add the `CanvasCompositor` namespace to your global scope. I like to assign it to a shorthand `cc`. 

You can then start using the CanvasCompositor's scene and graphics APIs by instantiating it with a canvas: 

```
var _cc = new CanvasCompositor.init(document.getElementById('myCanvas'));
```

Our `_cc` variable will expose some basic drawing functions (e.g.: `drawPath`, `drawRectangle`, `drawEllipse`, `drawText`, etc.) as well as a variety of classes (e.g.: `Path`, `Rectangle`, `Ellipse`, `Text`, etc.) that utilize them. 

The `_cc` variable will also have `Scene` property. If your only drawing pixels to canvas, this property is unnecessary, but if you intend to have any kind of animated or layered interactions, this object will be incredibly important. 

The `Scene` property is the entry point to your scene graph. It is of class `Container` (which is also exposed, and can be extended freely). `Container`s have `children` - the order of the `Scene`'s `children` determines the order in which they are drawn. 

`Container`s, like `Scene`, can have children added to them through the `addChild` method. The children can be `Container`s or any other inheritors of the `CanvasObject` class. 

`Container`s and `CanvasObject`s, in conjunction with `Rectangle`s, `Ellipse`s, `Text` etc., comprise an implementation of the [Composite Pattern](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Composite_pattern) - thus, "canvas-compositor". 

# Tests

At the moment, there are none. I'll probably get to that later.
